body: Bear Stearns and JPMorgan Chase came to a deal after the federal government got involved to prevent Bear Stearns from failing and causing deeper economic problems.
title: JPMorgan Chase agrees to buy Bear Stearns at deep discount
caption: Traders work the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on March 17, 2008 in New York City. Credit: Michael Nagle/Getty Images

body: Bank of America acquired the failing Countrywide Financial, one of California's largest lenders.
title: Bank of America acquires Countrywide
caption: A woman exits a Bank of America ATM branch Oct. 6, 2008 in New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: Denmark became the first European nation to confirm it was in a recession, defined by economists as two consecutive quarters of negative growth.
title: Denmark becomes first European nation to confirm recession
caption: Anders Fogh Rasmussen, Prime Minister of Denmark, speaks duirng the session "Rising to the Challenge of Copenhagen" at the World Economic Forum on Jan. 30, 2009. Credit: Eric Piermont/AFP/Getty Images

body: IndyMac Bank was seized by the federal government in what regulators said was the second largest U.S. bank failure ever.
title: Pasadena's IndyMac Bank seized by federal government
caption: Hundreds of nervous customers wait in line to get into an IndyMac Bank, open for the first time since the July 11 federal government takeover of the thrift, on July 14, 2008 in Pasadena. Credit: David McNew/Getty Images

body: Mortgage lenders Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by the federal government. Together, they were responsible for almost half of all outstanding home mortgages.
title: Lenders Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac bailed out
caption: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson speaks at a news conference announcing a federal takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Sept. 7, 2008 in Washington, D.C. Credit: Brendan Hoffman/Getty Images

body: Financial services firm Lehman Brothers files for bankruptcy, marking the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history and a key moment in the global financial crisis.
title: Lehman Brothers files for bankruptcy
caption: Men leave Lehman Brothers' Canary Wharf office carrying belongings on Sept. 15, 2008 in London, England. Credit: Cate Gillon/Getty Images

body: As Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, bank Merrill Lynch agreed to be taken over by Bank of America in a $50 billion deal.
title: Merrill Lynch taken over by Bank of America
caption: Bank of America CEO Ken Lewis (R) and Merrill Lynch CEO John Thain shake hands at a press conference at Bank of America headquarters Sept. 15, 2008 in New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: The Federal Reserve lended AIG $85 billion to help the insurance company avoid bankruptcy.
title: Federal Reserve bails out AIG
caption: People sit on steps outside of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) Sept. 16, 2008 in New York City. Credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images

body: Republican presidential nominee John McCain said that he would suspend his campaign to return to Washington and focus on the financial crisis, but officially resumed his campaign days later.
title: John McCain says he'll suspend campaign
caption: President George W. Bush (C) makes remarks on the economic crisis during a meeting with bipartisan and bicameral members of congress including the Presidential candidates Republican John McCain (L) and Barack Obama (R) in the Cabinet Room on Sept. 25, 2008 at the White House. Credit: Tim Sloan/AFP/Getty Images

body: The bank Washington Mutual was seized by the FDIC, which insures banks, and its assets were sold to JP MorganChase for $1.9 billion.
title: Washington Mutual seized by the FDIC
caption: A man is seen through the window of the Washington Mutual building the morning after it was seized by the FDIC and then sold to JP Morgan Chase Sept. 26, 2008 in Seattle, Washington. Credit: Robert Giroux/Getty Images

body: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 778 points, the largest single day drop in history.
title: Dow Jones has largest 1-day drop in history
caption: A trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange holds his head as he walks off the floor Sept. 29, 2008. Credit: Timothy A. Clary/AFP/Getty Images

body: President George W. Bush signed a $700 billion bailout, which started the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP). This allowed the government to buy troubled assets from banks and other financial institutions to keep those companies from going under.
title: President George W. Bush signs bailout, creating TARP
caption: President George W. Bush signs a Wall Street bailout bill in the Oval Office of the White House Oct. 3, 2008 in Washington, D.C. Credit: Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images

body: Despite it previously looking like Wachovia would be purchased by Citigroup, Wells Fargo made a higher offer and acquired the bank.
title: Wells Fargo acquires Wachovia
caption: A Wachovia branch bank is shown in Manhattan on Oct. 3, 2008 in New York. Credit: Timothy A. Clary/AFP/Getty Images

body: The Eurozone as a whole officially entered a recession, a day after Germany entered recession and the same day as Italy. France managed to grow by 0.1 percent in the quarter that sent the others officially into recession.
title: Eurozone enters recession
caption: President of the European Central Bank (ECB) Jean-Claude Trichet addresses a press conference at the bank's headquarters in Frankfurt/Main, January 15, 2009. Credit: John MacDougall/AFP/Getty Images

body: Japan officially enters a recession, its first since 2001. While it would experience some recovery in 2009, it fell back into recession in 2012.
title: Japan enters recession
caption: Japanese businessmen walk with their head down in Tokyo on Nov. 17, 2008. Credit: Yoshikazu Tsuno/AFP/Getty Images

body: In December 2008, the term "Great Recession" began to become a popular way to describe the economic downturn, though the same term has been used to describe various downturns for decades.
title: The term "Great Recession" takes hold
caption: A businessman watches a share prices board in Tokyo on Dec. 2, 2008. Credit: Yoshikazu Tsuno/AFP/Getty Images

body: Bernie Madoff was arrested for what he later admitted was a giant Ponzi scheme, believed to be the largest financial fraud in U.S. history.
title: Wealth manager Bernie Madoff arrested
caption: Bernard Madoff (R) arrives for federal court Jan. 14, 2009 in New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: The Great Recession included numerous layoffs from large corporations, including tens of thousands on one day in January 2009 from companies including GM, Sprint, Halliburton, Home Depot, Pfizer, Texas Instruments and Caterpillar.
title: 40,000 layoffs hit on one day
caption: Storm clouds hang in the sky above Quinn Co. Caterpillar on Jan. 26, 2009 in City of Industry, California. Credit: David McNew/Getty Images

body: Shortly after President Barack Obama took office, Congress passed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, estimated to cost $787 billion, which aimed to save jobs and stimulate the economy.
title: Congress passes American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
caption: The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act is put away after President Barack Obama signed it at the Denver Museum of Nature and Science in Denver, Colorado, Feb. 17, 2009. Credit: Jim Watson/AFP/Getty Images

body: In early 2009 the Obama administration introduced a $75 billion homeowner assistance program that aimed to help homeowners with underwater mortgages who were at risk of default and foreclosure.
title: Obama unveils $75 billion mortgage relief plan
caption: President Barack Obama waves to a crowd at Dobson High School on Feb. 18, 2009 in Mesa, Arizona. Credit: Michal Czerwonka/Getty Images

body: President Obama didn't deliver an official State of the Union in 2009, but addressed a joint session of Congress about the economic crisis, including TARP and the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, and laid out his plan for recovery.
title: Obama speaks to Congress about the economy
caption: President Barack Obama addresses a joint session of Congress in the House Chamber of the Capitol in Washington on Feb. 24, 2009. Credit: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Pool/AFP/Getty Images

body: Chrysler filed for bankruptcy protection, with a plan including the United Auto Workers taking control of the company and Fiat and the U.S. government holding minority stakes.
title: Chrysler files for bankruptcy protection

body: GM filed for bankruptcy, following the U.S. government providing funding and guaranteeing GM's liability as it sought to reorganize.
title: GM files for bankruptcy

body: Economists have marked June 2009 as the official end of the recession, though economic problems continued to plague Americans, including high unemployment.
title: Official end of the recession
caption: A builder works on a new multi-story housing complex in Los Angeles on June 16, 2009. Credit: Mark Ralston/AFP/Getty Images

body: In August 2009, California's joblessness rate hit 12.2 percent, the highest in 70 years.
title: California joblessness hits 12.2 percent
caption: Job seekers line up to enter Choice Career Fair at the Los Angeles Convention Center on Dec. 1, 2010. Credit: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images

body: While Obama's mortgage relief plan was in place, homeowners continued to struggle. Out of 4 million eligible homeowners, 230,000 had taken advantage of it by September, according to the Treasury Department.
title: Homeowners continue to struggle with mortgages

body: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued Goldman Sachs for fraud, due to not disclosing information about a mortgage-backed CDO that was allegedly "designed to fail" and profit a hedge fund by betting against it.
title: SEC sues Goldman Sachs for fraud
caption: A man enters Goldman Sachs' new headquarters in Lower Manhattan April 16, 2010 in New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: Standard & Poor's downgraded the United States' credit rating, an important measure of how likely the country is to pay back its debts. That rating influences interest rates and how easy it is for the nation to borrow money.
title: United States loses AAA credit rating
caption: An ABC News ticker reads "Standard & Poor's downgrades US credit rating from AAA to AA+" in Times Square on Aug. 5, 2011 in New York City. Credit: Andrew Burton/Getty Images

body: Occupy Wall Street protesters set up camp in the heart of New York City's Financial District in order to bring attention to economic inequality. The group and its rallying cry "We are the 99 percent" spread across the nation.
title: Occupy Wall Street protesters set up camp on Wall Street
caption: Demonstrators opposed to corporate profits on Wall Street march against police brutality on Sept. 30, 2011 New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: Protesters marched in solidarity with those in New York and elsewhere, setting up camp outside L.A. City Hall as they protested economic inequality.
title: Occupy movement spreads to L.A.
caption: Protesters hold signs as they march to Los Angeles City Hall during the "Occupy Los Angeles" demonstration in solidarity with the ongoing "Occupy Wall Street" protest in New York City on Oct. 1, 2011. Credit: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images

body: The Inland Empire was one of the areas hardest hit by the recession, and in an October 2011 report released in November that year, the area took the number 4 spot on the foreclosure list while Las Vegas lost its number 1 spot to Stockton.
title: Inland Empire still hit hard by foreclosures
caption: A vacant bank-owned house in deteriorating condition drags down neighborhood property prices on Aug. 25, 2008 in Moreno Valley, California. Credit: David McNew/Getty Images

body: Almost 200 people were arrested as New York City police raided the Occupy Wall Street camp, forcing out the protesters.
title: Occupy protesters forced out of New York City's Zuccotti Park
caption: Occupy Wall Street activists march through downtown Manhattan after police removed the protesters early in the morning from Zuccotti Park on November 15, 2011 in New York City. Credit: Allison Joyce/Getty Images

body: After receiving a deadline to leave from L.A. Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, many protesters remained, leading to a raid by the LAPD and 292 arrests.
title: LAPD raids and shuts down Occupy L.A. camp

body: A survey released in February 2013 showed that nearly eight in 10 knew someone who had lost their job during or after the recession.
title: Survey: Recession layoffs affected almost everyone
caption: People wait in line to enter the Diversity Job Fair at the Affinia Hotel June 10, 2008 in New York City. Credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

body: As the Southland housing market began to pick up steam once again, investors flipped 1,377 homes in May 2013.
title: Southland home flipping reaches highest level since June 2005
caption: A reduced price sign sits in front of a house Nov. 27, 2007 in Glendale. Credit: David McNew/Getty Images

body: President Obama gave a major economic speech, saying that the U.S. had "fought its way back" from the economic turmoil the country faced when he took office.
title: Obama delivers major economic speech, declares end to "Great Recession"
caption: President Barack Obama addresses the state of the economy during a speech at Knox College on July 24, 2013 in Galesburg, Illinois. Credit: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images
